original.A: You successfully found the main idea by noticing the author describes eclipses as special, exciting events in the sky. The text supports this when it says “something special called an eclipse can take place” and that eclipses are “big news.” Remember to ask yourself, “What is this mostly about?” and look for clue words like special, interesting, or rare in future questions.
original.B: You may have focused on the safety warning, but the text says, “You must never look directly at a solar eclipse,” which is just a warning, while also calling eclipses “something special” and “interesting things to look at.” This shows the main idea is that eclipses are fascinating natural events, not that they’re too dangerous to study. Next time, make sure your answer matches the big idea of the whole passage, not just one detail.
original.C: You may have brought in an outside idea about which is more important, but the text says “the moon does not give off light… It simply reflects light from the sun,” so it never says the moon is more important than the sun. The passage mostly explains solar and lunar eclipses, that they are rare and even “big news,” so the correct answer is that eclipses are fascinating natural events. Next time, stick to what the text says and choose the answer that matches the big idea of the whole passage, not an idea from outside.
original.D: You may have focused on the safety rule and thought only scientists should watch, but the text says lunar eclipses “can be seen from half of Earth” and that an eclipse “is usually big news,” so lots of people watch them (with care). The big idea is that eclipses are special and interesting to see, so “Eclipses are fascinating natural events” is correct. Strategy: Look for clue words like “interesting” and “special,” and make sure your answer fits the whole passage, not just one sentence.

original.A: Incorrect. This reverses the actual progression. The passage states ancient civilizations 'used just their naked eye' and space probes are modern technology. Space probes that 'landed on Mars' represent current exploration methods, not ancient ones, making this sequence backwards.
original.B: Correct! The passage explicitly contrasts ancient methods with modern ones: 'Long ago, people...used just their naked eye to study the planets' versus 'Now, we have telescopes and other amazing tools that help us get a much better look at the planets.' This shows clear progression from simple observation to technology-assisted viewing.
original.C: Incorrect. Telescopes are modern tools, not ancient ones. The passage places telescopes in the 'Now' category of modern tools, and robots exploring Mars are also current technology. Ancient people didn't have access to either telescopes or robots for planetary observation.
original.D: Incorrect. This reverses reality and misrepresents the passage. Photographs require cameras, which are modern technology. The passage describes ancient people using 'naked eye' observation without tools, and doesn't indicate they had photographic technology thousands of years ago.

rewritten.A: Good try! The story says scientists thought Venus and Earth were similar because they are close to each other. Being neighbors made them think they were alike, not different.
rewritten.B: Nice thinking, but the different orbit times aren't why scientists changed their minds. The story talks about something else that made Venus seem very different from Earth.
rewritten.C: You got it! The story says scientists found out Venus is "much hotter than Earth" and not good for living. The hot temperature proved Venus was very different from Earth.
rewritten.D: Not quite! Scientists don't use planet names to decide if planets are similar. The story talks about what Venus is actually like, not what people called it.

original.A: Incorrect. Positional difference was already known and actually supported the similarity idea since the planets are neighbors. The passage presents their proximity ('Venus...is the planet closest to Earth') as a reason scientists initially thought they were similar, not as contradictory evidence.
original.B: Incorrect. Different orbital periods aren't presented as the reason scientists rejected the similarity theory. While the passage mentions these different orbital times in paragraph 2, this information appears in a section about orbital mechanics, not in paragraph 3 where scientists' changed conclusions about Venus are discussed.
original.C: Correct! The passage explicitly states scientists 'discovered that their idea about Venus was completely wrong' and explains 'They have now concluded that Venus is much hotter than Earth and would not be a good place for us to live or even visit.' Temperature is presented as the key evidence that contradicted similarity expectations.
original.D: Incorrect. Names reflect human cultural choices, not planetary characteristics that would affect similarity. The passage discusses naming as historical/cultural information separate from scientific properties. Scientists wouldn't reject a similarity theory based on what humans chose to call planets.

rewritten.A: Good try! The story talks about many different planets, not just focusing on Mars. It mentions Mercury, Venus, Earth, and Mars all getting studied.
rewritten.B: Great job! The story shows people went from using "just their naked eye" to having "telescopes and other amazing tools." This shows how studying planets got much better over time!
rewritten.C: Not quite! The story never says old people thought planets didn't move. It says ancient people were interested in planets and watched them in the sky.
rewritten.D: Nice thinking, but the story actually shows planets are very different from each other! It says Venus and Earth are different in many important ways.

original.A: Incorrect. The passage doesn't show a shift to Mars-only focus. While Mars receives detailed attention in paragraph 4, the passage discusses multiple planets throughout (Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars, Neptune) and doesn't suggest scientists abandoned studying other planets to concentrate exclusively on Mars.
original.B: Correct! The passage traces this progression across multiple sections: paragraph 1 describes ancient 'naked eye' observation, then modern 'telescopes and other amazing tools'; paragraph 4 shows advanced investigation with 'space probes and robots' that 'have taken thousands of photographs and dug up rocks to study.' This demonstrates evolution from basic viewing to sophisticated technological exploration.
original.C: Incorrect. The passage never suggests ancient people didn't understand planets moved. It states that ancient civilizations 'were all interested in the planets' and observed them, implying they recognized planetary motion. The passage presents orbital movement as established knowledge, not a contested idea.
original.D: Incorrect. This contradicts the passage's message about planet diversity. The Venus section specifically shows scientists learned planets are different, not identical: 'Venus and Earth are different in many important ways.' The passage emphasizes discovering differences between planets, not similarities or sameness.

rewritten.A: Good try! The Mars robots are cool, but that doesn't show scientists changing their minds. The story shows scientists changed their ideas when they learned Venus wasn't like Earth.
rewritten.B: Great job! You found how scientists first thought Venus was like Earth but then "discovered they were wrong." This shows scientists change their minds when they learn new things.
rewritten.C: Nice thinking, but the ancient people using their eyes doesn't show scientists changing ideas. The story shows scientists changed their minds about Venus being like Earth.
rewritten.D: Not quite! Mercury taking 88 days is a true fact, but it doesn't show changing ideas. The story shows scientists changed their minds about Venus.

original.A: You may have focused on a cool detail about Mars, but look at “But scientists discovered that their idea about Venus was completely wrong” and “They have now concluded that Venus is much hotter than Earth,” which shows the main point is that scientists once thought Venus was like Earth but learned they were wrong. The Mars line, “Many space probes and robots have landed on Mars,” is just a supporting detail; next time, reread the question and pick the sentence that matches clue words like “scientists discovered.”
original.B: You successfully found the main idea by noticing how the author first explains what scientists used to think and then shows how that idea changed. The text supports this when it says, “For a long time, scientists thought that Venus might be very similar to Earth… But scientists discovered that their idea about Venus was completely wrong.” When answering similar questions, ask yourself “What is this mostly about?” and look for clue words like “but” that show a change in ideas.
original.C: It looks like you focused on a detail from the beginning (ancient people used their “naked eye”), but the question asks what scientists learned about Venus. The text says, “For a long time, scientists thought that Venus might be very similar to Earth… But scientists discovered that their idea about Venus was completely wrong,” so the correct answer is that they thought it was like Earth but learned it wasn’t. Next time, reread the question and choose the answer that matches the part of the text about that topic.
original.D: You may have focused on a true supporting detail, but it’s about Mercury, not the Venus idea the question asks about; the text says, “It needs just 88 days to make one orbit around the sun.” Instead, look at the Venus section: “But scientists discovered that their idea about Venus was completely wrong,” and they now know it is “much hotter than Earth,” which matches the correct answer. Next time, reread the question and pick the detail that matches its topic, not just any interesting fact.

rewritten.A: Good try! Ice doesn't explain why Mars looks red in the sky. The story says Mars looks red because of rust on its rocks.
rewritten.B: Great job! The story says "if there is water on Mars, there might be life there too." Scientists got excited because ice means water, and water might mean life!
rewritten.C: Not quite! Ice doesn't make planets move faster around the sun. The story says how close planets are to the sun changes their speed.
rewritten.D: Nice thinking, but Mars was named after a war god long ago. The ice discovery is exciting for a different reason about life.

original.A: Incorrect. Ice doesn't prove or explain Mars's red appearance - rust does. The passage clearly states 'This red color comes from rocks on Mars that contain rust,' presenting rust and ice as separate, unrelated discoveries. Ice's excitement isn't connected to color.
original.B: Correct! The passage explains the significance immediately after stating excitement: 'Ice is frozen water, and if there is water on Mars, there might be life there too.' This causal chain (ice → water → potential life) directly explains why scientists found the ice discovery exciting and important.
original.C: Incorrect. Orbital speed relates to distance from sun, not ice presence. Paragraph 2 explains Mars's orbital period (not mentioned as faster than Earth's 365 days) is determined by distance, not by surface features like ice. These are completely separate topics in different paragraphs.
original.D: Incorrect. Mars's name comes from Roman mythology about war, unrelated to ice or scientific discoveries. The passage presents naming as cultural/historical information from paragraph 4's opening, while ice's significance relates to the scientific question of life, making these distinct topics.

rewritten.A: Good try! The story shows that scientists DO change their ideas when they learn new things. They "had to change their ideas" about Venus when they found out it wasn't like Earth.
rewritten.B: Great job! The story shows scientists "had to change their ideas" about Venus when they learned new facts. This is how science works - people change what they think when they discover new things.
rewritten.C: Not quite! Scientists study much more than what ancient people saw. The story tells us about space robots on Mars and other discoveries that ancient people could never have made.
rewritten.D: Nice thinking, but no! Scientists love studying planets that look different from Earth. Mars looks "quite red" and different, but scientists still send space robots there to explore it.

original.A: Incorrect. This directly contradicts the Venus example. The passage emphasizes that scientists 'had to change their ideas when they learned new facts about Venus,' showing they don't maintain original theories when evidence contradicts them. The word 'had to' stresses the necessity of revision.
original.B: Correct! The Venus example demonstrates this principle: scientists initially 'thought that Venus might be very similar to Earth' but 'discovered that their idea about Venus was completely wrong' and changed their conclusion when they 'learned new facts.' This illustrates how scientific knowledge evolves through evidence-based revision across paragraphs 3-4.
original.C: Incorrect. The passage shows scientists study planets beyond ancient observations. While paragraph 1 mentions ancient civilizations observed planets, modern scientists investigate details impossible for ancient observers - like Mars ice discovered by probes, surface composition, and planetary temperatures - showing expanded study beyond ancient knowledge.
original.D: Incorrect. The passage shows scientists actively investigate diverse planets. Mars is 'quite red' and explicitly different from Earth in appearance, yet 'Many space probes and robots have landed on Mars to explore this interesting planet.' Scientists' Mars investigation contradicts any supposed refusal to study different-looking planets.

rewritten.A: Good try! This tells us what old people did, but it doesn't compare them to today's scientists. The question asks which sentence shows modern scientists can learn MORE than ancient people.
rewritten.B: Not quite! This is just a basic fact about how planets move around the sun. Both old and new scientists could figure this out by watching the sky.
rewritten.C: You got it! The phrase "thousands of photographs and dug up rocks" shows modern scientists can do much more than ancient people. Old scientists could only look with their eyes!
rewritten.D: Nice thinking, but this just lists the four closest planets. Ancient people could see these planets too by looking at the night sky, so it doesn't show modern scientists know more.

original.A: Incorrect. This sentence describes ancient observation methods but doesn't make a comparison showing modern superiority. It tells what ancient people did but doesn't demonstrate that modern methods gather more detailed information - it only describes one approach without contrasting capabilities.
original.B: Incorrect. This is basic astronomical knowledge available to both ancient and modern observers. The sentence states a general fact about planetary motion that ancient observers could recognize by watching planets move across the sky over time, so it doesn't distinguish modern capabilities.
original.C: Correct! This sentence demonstrates modern technology's detailed investigation capabilities. Taking 'thousands of photographs' and 'dug up rocks to study' represents information-gathering impossible for ancient observers who only viewed planets from Earth. This shows the depth and detail modern technology enables compared to simple visual observation.
original.D: Incorrect. This classification of inner planets states information without showing how it was gathered. While modern scientists may have confirmed this through detailed study, ancient observers could also identify the four closest planets through careful naked-eye observation, so this doesn't demonstrate modern superiority in detail-gathering.

rewritten.A: Good try! The story talks about rocky surfaces, but that's not what makes planets orbit fast or slow. Distance from the sun is what matters for orbit time.
rewritten.B: Nice thinking, but planet names don't change how they move! The story shows that distance from the sun decides how long orbits take, not what we call the planets.
rewritten.C: You got it! The story says "the closer a planet is to the sun, the less time it needs to make one orbit." Mercury is closest and fastest!
rewritten.D: Not quite! When people discovered planets doesn't change how the planets move. The story shows that distance from the sun controls orbit time.

original.A: Incorrect. Surface type doesn't determine orbital time - distance does. The passage mentions 'rocky, solid surfaces' for inner planets but presents this as a descriptive feature separate from the orbital mechanics discussion. Mercury, Venus, Earth, and Mars all have rocky surfaces but very different orbital times (88, 225, 365 days).
original.B: Incorrect. Planet names don't affect orbital physics. While Mercury (88 days) and Venus (225 days) were named after Roman deities and orbit faster than Earth (365 days), Mars (also named for a Roman god) isn't stated to orbit faster than Earth. The passage presents naming as cultural, not physical-mechanical, information.
original.C: Correct! The passage explicitly establishes this principle: 'The closer a planet is to the sun, the less time it needs to make one orbit.' Examples support this: Mercury (closest, 88 days), Venus (225 days), Earth (365 days), Neptune (farthest mentioned, 165 years), showing clear correlation between distance and orbital duration.
original.D: Incorrect. Discovery history doesn't affect orbital mechanics. Ancient civilizations could observe certain planets, but when humans discovered or observed planets doesn't influence how long those planets take to orbit. Orbital time depends on physical distance from the sun, not observation history.

rewritten.A: Great job! You saw that the passage teaches facts about "the outer planets." The story explains what these planets are like and how they're different from Earth.
rewritten.B: Good try! The passage talks about planets but doesn't give tips for traveling to space. It teaches facts about what the outer planets are like instead.
rewritten.C: Nice thinking, but the story mentions Jupiter's storm, not Earth's weather. The passage teaches about "the outer planets" and what makes them special.
rewritten.D: Close! The story mentions telescopes but doesn't teach how to use them. It focuses on teaching facts about the four outer planets instead.

original.A: You successfully identified the author’s purpose by seeing that the passage teaches facts about the outer planets. The text supports this with the title “The Outer Planets: Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune” and details like “Scientists call these planets gas giants” and “Saturn is famous for… rings.” Remember to check the title and first sentences and ask, “What is the author trying to teach me?” for similar questions.
original.B: You may have thought the passage gave tips for space travel, but it never gives directions or advice; instead it explains facts like “The outer planets are very different from Earth… made mostly of gas,” and tells about Jupiter’s storm and Saturn’s rings. This shows the purpose is to help readers learn about the outer planets. Next time, check the title and what the text repeats the most to be sure your answer matches the main idea.
original.C: You may have focused on the word “storm” and thought the passage was about Earth’s weather, but the title “The Outer Planets: Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune” and details about gas giants, rings, and which planets are farthest from the sun show it’s teaching about the outer planets, not Earth’s weather. The correct answer is “to help readers learn about outer planets” because the text explains facts about Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune. Strategy: Next time, check the title and repeated ideas to be sure your answer matches what the whole passage is mostly about, not just one detail.
original.D: You may have focused on a supporting detail—the line “You need a telescope to see Neptune”—but the passage never gives steps or instructions for using a telescope. The title and most paragraphs list and describe the outer planets (their order, size, gas, rings, and moons), so the purpose is to help readers learn about the outer planets. Strategy: Check that your answer matches what the whole passage and title are mostly about, not just one sentence.

rewritten.A: Great job! The author wants you to "ask the adults in your family how many planets there are." This shows you should share what you learned!
rewritten.B: Good try! The story tells us the planet names, but it doesn't say you need to memorize them right away.

original.A: Correct! The author directly suggests this action in Section 4, saying 'Try asking the adults in your family how many planets there are.' This shows the author wants readers to use what they learned by testing adults' knowledge, which reflects the author's purpose of educating readers about current planet information.
original.B: Incorrect. While the author does list the planets in order, there is no suggestion in the passage that readers need to memorize them immediately. The author's tone is informational and conversational, not demanding memorization.
original.C: Incorrect. The passage mentions that telescopes help see distant planets like Neptune, but the author never suggests readers should build their own telescope. This confuses mentioned information with the author's intended purpose.
original.D: Incorrect. Although the passage discusses how scientists changed their classification of Pluto, the author never encourages readers to contact scientists. The author simply explains what scientists decided, not asking readers to challenge that decision.

rewritten.A: Good try! The story tells us Jupiter has many moons, but that's not why the author compares Jupiter's size to Earth. The author wants to show how big Jupiter is.
rewritten.B: Great job! The author says "1,300 Earths could fit inside it!" This helps you picture just how huge Jupiter really is.
rewritten.C: Nice thinking, but the author isn't trying to teach about what Earth is made of. The comparison is all about showing Jupiter's giant size.
rewritten.D: Not quite! The story never says gas planets are dangerous. The author compares sizes to help you understand how big Jupiter is.

original.A: Incorrect. While Jupiter does have 63 moons, the author does not connect the size comparison to the number of moons. These are presented as separate facts about Jupiter in Section 2.
original.B: Correct! In Section 2, the author states 'It is so big that 1,300 Earths could fit inside it!' This comparison gives readers a concrete way to visualize Jupiter's enormous size by relating it to something familiar (Earth). The author's point of view is that using familiar comparisons helps readers understand unfamiliar concepts.
original.C: Incorrect. The passage does mention that gas giants differ from rocky inner planets, but the size comparison to Earth is not used to explain what Earth is made of. This reverses the author's purpose.
original.D: Incorrect. The passage never suggests that gas planets are dangerous. The author mentions Jupiter's storm, but the size comparison is not connected to any danger - it's simply to show scale.

rewritten.A: Great job! The story shows that scientists 'changed their minds' about Pluto in 2006. This tells us that what scientists know can change as they learn more.
rewritten.B: Good try! The story mentions adults learned about nine planets, but it's just explaining what happened before. The author doesn't say adults know less than kids.
rewritten.C: Not quite! The author says scientists 'removed Pluto's name from the list' and accepts there are eight planets now. The story agrees with the scientists' decision.
rewritten.D: Nice thinking, but the story gives much more details about Jupiter and Saturn than Pluto. The author talks about Pluto to explain why the number changed.

original.A: Correct! In Section 4, the author explains how scientists changed their minds about Pluto in 2006 after looking 'more carefully' and deciding it 'did not have all the right characteristics.' This shows the author's point of view that science involves ongoing learning and that classifications can change as we gain better understanding.
original.B: Incorrect. The author mentions that adults learned about nine planets in school, but this is used to explain historical context, not to suggest adults are less knowledgeable than children. The author's tone is respectful toward both groups.
original.C: Incorrect. The author clearly states scientists 'removed Pluto's name from the list' and 'now there are only eight planets.' This shows the author accepts the current scientific classification, not that there should be nine.
original.D: Incorrect. The author actually provides much more detail about Jupiter and Saturn than Pluto. The Pluto information serves to explain why planet counts changed, not because Pluto itself is especially interesting.

rewritten.A: Good try! The author explains things clearly and uses exciting words, not confused words. The author knows a lot about the outer planets and shares cool facts.
rewritten.B: Nice thinking, but the author thinks Jupiter's storm is cool, not scary! The author says it "looks like a big eye!" with excitement, not worry.
rewritten.C: You got it! The author uses exciting words like "looks like a big eye!" and shows amazement about how big Jupiter is. The author thinks the outer planets are really cool!
rewritten.D: Not quite! The author mentions they're far away but doesn't sound sad about it. The author is excited to tell us amazing facts about these far-off planets.

original.A: Incorrect. The author uses clear, confident language throughout the passage to explain the outer planets. Words like 'special,' 'beautiful,' and exclamation marks show enthusiasm, not confusion.
original.B: Incorrect. While the author mentions Jupiter's giant storm, there is no worried or cautionary tone. The author presents this as an interesting fact ('It looks like a big eye!') rather than something concerning.
original.C: Correct! Throughout the passage, the author uses enthusiastic language showing fascination: 'very special' (about Saturn's rings), 'beautiful' (about Saturn), 'It looks like a big eye!' (about Jupiter's storm), and exclamation marks to show excitement. This reveals the author's point of view that the outer planets are amazing and worth learning about.
original.D: Incorrect. While the author notes the outer planets are far away, this is stated as fact, not with disappointment. The author maintains an excited, positive tone about these distant worlds throughout the passage.

rewritten.A: Good try! The story doesn't show what causes things to happen. It just tells facts about Jupiter like "Jupiter is the largest" and gives examples.
rewritten.B: Nice thinking, but the story doesn't compare planets to show how they're different. It describes Jupiter and gives examples like "1,300 Earths could fit inside it!"
rewritten.C: Great job! You spotted that the story describes Jupiter and gives examples like "Jupiter is the largest." The story tells what Jupiter is like with facts and examples.
rewritten.D: Close! The planets are in order, but the story isn't giving steps to follow. It describes what Jupiter is like with examples like "1,300 Earths could fit inside it!"

original.A: You may have picked cause and effect because one line says, “Because they are so far away, they are very cold,” but most of the passage lists facts, like “Jupiter is the largest” and “Saturn has rings made of ice and dust.” That means the text is description with examples—it describes the outer planets and gives examples of their features (Jupiter’s big storm, Saturn’s rings, their moons). Strategy: Check what the whole passage mostly does—does it explain why things happen, or does it describe and give examples?
original.B: You may have thought it was comparison and contrast because it mentions outer vs. inner planets, but most of the passage simply gives facts and examples about each planet—“Jupiter is the largest… 1,300 Earths could fit inside it” and “Saturn has rings made of ice and dust.” That means the right answer is description with examples, not comparison and contrast. Next time, ask: Is the author mostly telling how things are alike/different (look for words like both, unlike), or describing each thing with facts and examples?
original.C: You successfully identified the text structure as description with examples by noticing how the author tells what the outer planets are like and then gives specific examples. The text supports this when it says, 'Of all the planets, Jupiter is the largest. It is so big that 1,300 Earths could fit inside it!' and 'It [Saturn] has many large rings… These rings are made of ice and dust.' Remember: when you see lots of describing words and facts (especially numbers) that show examples, think “description with examples.”
original.D: You may have focused on the order of planets (Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, Neptune) and thought it was a sequence of steps, but notice the text isn’t telling how to do something—it describes each planet and gives examples, like “Jupiter is the largest… 1,300 Earths could fit inside it” and “Saturn has rings made of ice and dust.” The correct structure is description with examples because it lists characteristics and examples for each outer planet. Strategy: Ask yourself, “Is this giving instructions in order, or describing things with facts and examples?”

rewritten.A: Good try! The sentences tell us what Saturn's rings are made of, but they don't explain why Saturn has rings. They describe the rings, not why they exist.
rewritten.B: Great job! The sentences describe what the rings are like - "ice and dust" - and explain why they look bright. They tell us the ice reflects sunlight to make bright rings.
rewritten.C: Nice thinking, but this section only talks about Saturn's rings. It doesn't compare Saturn's rings to Jupiter's moons at all.
rewritten.D: Not quite! The sentences tell us what the rings are made of and why they shine. They don't explain the steps of how the rings were formed.

original.A: Incorrect. The sentences describe what the rings look like and are made of, but they do not explain why Saturn has rings in the first place. The passage tells what they are, not why they exist.
original.B: Correct! Section 3 uses description with explanation: First, it describes what the rings are made of ('ice and dust'). Then it explains why they shine ('The ice reflects light from the sun'). Finally, it describes their appearance ('bright rings'). This is a descriptive pattern that provides details and reasons for those details.
original.C: Incorrect. While both Saturn's rings and Jupiter's moons are mentioned in the passage, Section 3 does not compare them to each other. Section 3 focuses only on describing Saturn's rings.
original.D: Incorrect. The sentences describe what the rings are made of and why they shine, but they do not explain the process or steps of how the rings were formed over time. There is no sequence showing ring formation.

rewritten.A: Good try! The story talks about moons and distance, but it doesn't say planets closer to the sun have more moons. The story keeps these facts separate.
rewritten.B: Great job! The story says planets "are very cold places" because they are far from the sun. Distance from the sun makes planets colder!
rewritten.C: Nice thinking, but the story mentions Jupiter's storm without connecting it to being close to the sun. Jupiter isn't even the closest planet!
rewritten.D: Not quite! The story says some planets are "hard to see," not hard to name. All eight planets are clearly named in the story.

original.A: Incorrect. While the passage mentions that Jupiter and Saturn have many moons, it does not connect the number of moons to distance from the sun. This confuses two separate facts from the passage.
original.B: Correct! In Section 3, the author makes a clear cause-and-effect connection: 'These planets are the farthest from the sun. Because they are so far away, they are very cold places.' The word 'because' shows the logical connection - distance from the sun causes the temperature to be cold.
original.C: Incorrect. The passage mentions Jupiter's giant storm, but Jupiter is not the closest planet to the sun. The author does not connect storm size to distance from the sun anywhere in the passage.
original.D: Incorrect. The passage does say Uranus and Neptune are hard to see, but it does not suggest they are harder to name. All eight planets are clearly named in the passage regardless of their distance.

rewritten.A: Good try! The story says Uranus is "hard to see" and Neptune is "impossible to see without help." Not all planets are easy to see.
rewritten.B: Nice thinking, but the story doesn't list all eight planets from easiest to hardest to see. It only talks about how hard Uranus and Neptune are to see.
rewritten.C: You got it! The story says "You need a telescope to see Neptune." It shows that faraway planets need special tools to be seen.
rewritten.D: Not quite! The story doesn't tell us how Earth looks or compare Earth to Neptune. It only talks about whether we can see Neptune.

original.A: Incorrect. Section 1 actually states the opposite - it says Uranus is 'hard to see' and Neptune is 'impossible to see without help.' Not all planets are easy to see.
original.B: Incorrect. While Section 1 mentions visibility of Uranus and Neptune, it does not list all eight planets in order from easiest to hardest to see. It only discusses the difficulty of seeing these two specific planets.
original.C: Correct! Section 1 makes a logical progression about visibility: Uranus is hard to see with just eyes, Neptune is impossible without help, then explains you need a telescope (a tool). The connection between sentences builds from problem (can't see) to solution (need telescope), showing that distance affects visibility and creates need for tools.
original.D: Incorrect. Section 1 does not describe how Earth looks or compare its appearance to Neptune's appearance. It only discusses whether Neptune can be seen and what tools are needed.

rewritten.A: You got it! The first sentence says gas giants are "so huge," and the second sentence shows this by telling us Jupiter is the biggest planet.
rewritten.B: Good try! But these sentences don't disagree with each other. They both say the same thing about outer planets being really big.
rewritten.C: Not quite! The second sentence doesn't say the first one is wrong. It actually helps prove that gas giants really are huge.
rewritten.D: Nice thinking, but these sentences aren't about things happening in time order. They're both just telling us how big the planets are.

original.A: Correct! The first sentence makes a general statement about gas giants being 'huge,' and the second sentence provides a specific example by naming Jupiter as the largest planet. This is an example-support relationship where the specific case (Jupiter) illustrates the general claim (gas giants are huge). This requires analyzing how two sentences work together logically.
original.B: Incorrect. The sentences do not contradict each other. Both sentences support the same idea that the outer planets are very large. 'Contradict' would mean they disagree, but they actually agree and work together.
original.C: Incorrect. The second sentence does not show the first is wrong - instead, it supports and strengthens the first sentence by giving Jupiter as proof that gas giants are indeed huge.
original.D: Incorrect. These sentences are not describing events in time order. They are describing characteristics of planets (size), not events that happen in sequence. There is no time relationship between these sentences.

rewritten.A: Great job! The story clearly says "makes faraway things look bigger and closer," which tells us exactly what a telescope helps you do.
rewritten.B: Good try! The story talks about Saturn but never says when its rings were made. The story does tell us what telescopes do though!
rewritten.C: Nice thinking, but the story says Jupiter's storm has gone on for hundreds of years without saying when it will stop. Look for what the story says about telescopes!
rewritten.D: Not quite! The story mentions Neptune but doesn't tell us who found it first. The story does explain what telescopes help us do though!

original.A: Great job identifying key details to answer a specific question. The passage says, “A telescope is a special tool that makes faraway things look bigger and closer,” which clearly tells what a telescope helps you do. Remember: when a question asks what something is or does, look for a sentence in the text that gives a definition or explanation.
original.B: It looks like you chose a question the passage doesn’t answer; it says Saturn’s rings are made of ice and dust and that they shine, but it never tells when they were made. The text does state, “A telescope is a special tool that makes faraway things look bigger and closer,” which answers the correct question: What does a telescope help you do? Next time, reread and pick the question you can answer directly with a sentence from the passage.

The passage does answer “What does a telescope help you do?” by saying a telescope makes faraway things look bigger and closer. original.A: Great job identifying key details by naming each stage: meteoroid in space, meteor in the atmosphere, and meteorite on the ground. The text supports this when it says, “When a meteoroid flies into Earth’s atmosphere, we call it a meteor,” and “If a meteor doesn’t burn up… the pieces… are called meteorites” that can make a crater. For similar questions, look for bold words and clues like when/if, and track what happens first, next, and last.
original.B: You may have switched the names at each step, but the text says, “There are…rocks called meteoroids” in space, “When a meteoroid flies into Earth’s atmosphere, we call it a meteor,” and “The pieces…found on the ground are called meteorites,” so calling it a meteorite in space or a meteor on the ground is backwards. The correct order is: in space it’s a meteoroid, in the air it’s a meteor (the bright streak), and on the ground it’s a meteorite that can make a crater. Strategy: Reread and match each word to the location clue words—space, atmosphere (air), ground—and make sure your answer follows that order.
original.C: You may have thought all meteors hit the ground and make big holes, but the passage says, “Most meteors burn up completely in the atmosphere,” and only those that don’t burn up can land as meteorites and make a crater. The correct idea is: in space it’s a meteoroid, in Earth’s air it’s a meteor with a bright streak, and only some survive to become meteorites that might make a crater. Tip: watch for clue words like most, some, or all, and reread the sentence that answers the question.
original.D: It looks like you switched the names and added comets: the text says “When a meteoroid flies into Earth’s atmosphere, we call it a meteor” (the bright streak), and “The pieces… on the ground are called meteorites,” while comets are icy snowballs with tails. So the right chain is: in space = meteoroid; in Earth’s air (bright streak) = meteor; on the ground = meteorite (can make a crater). Tip: reread the definition lines and make a quick space→air→ground list to check your answer next time.

rewritten.A: Good try! The story says comets get their bright tail first when they get close to the sun. Then people can see the tail from Earth.

Then this gas streams behind the comet creating the bright tail. This shows the cause-effect relationship between the sun's heat and the tail's formation.

rewritten.A: Great job! The story says asteroids "group together like a giant ring around the sun" between Mars and Jupiter. Scientists call this the asteroid belt because it looks like a belt around our solar system.

The passage then states that 'Scientists call this the asteroid belt because it looks like a belt wrapped around our solar system.' This shows the connection between their location and appearance.
original.B: This is incorrect. The passage states that asteroids group together in the asteroid belt between Mars and Jupiter - they are not scattered randomly. Also, the passage explains that meteors, not asteroids, burn up in the atmosphere and create shooting stars.
original.C: This is incorrect. This description matches Halley's Comet from Section 2, not asteroids. The passage says Halley's Comet 'can be seen from Earth without a telescope every 76 years,' but asteroids are described as being in a belt between Mars and Jupiter.
original.D: This is incorrect. Asteroids orbit in space in the asteroid belt - they are not on Earth's surface. The passage explains that meteorites (not asteroids) are space rock pieces found on the ground, and they can create craters when they land.

rewritten.A: Good try! The story says meteors "rush through the atmosphere" and burn up, not float gently down. Most meteors burn up completely before reaching the ground.

The meteor's fast movement through the atmosphere causes friction that makes it burn, and this burning is what creates the visible bright trail that people observe.
original.D: This is incorrect. This choice confuses comets with meteors. Section 2 explains that comets get bright tails near the sun, but they do not crash into Earth to make craters. Section 4 explains that only some meteors (as meteorites) make craters, not comets.

This is called a meteor shower, and it creates an amazing space show that can last for several nights.' The passage shows that a meteor shower is simply many individual meteors occurring together.

rewritten.B: Great job! The story shows scientists "studied the ideas of another scientist named Albert Einstein" to make new discoveries. Scientists help each other learn!
rewritten.C: Not quite! The story doesn't show scientists fighting about ideas. It shows them working together to build the Big Bang Theory.
rewritten.D: Nice thinking, but the story says the opposite! The scientists "studied the ideas of another scientist named Albert Einstein" from the past.

original.A: Incorrect. The passage shows the opposite - three scientists worked together studying Einstein's ideas to develop the Big Bang Theory. This demonstrates collaboration, not isolated work. Review paragraph 2 to see how scientists explicitly worked together and built on Einstein's prior work.
original.B: Correct! The passage shows Lemaitre, Friedmann, and Hubble studying Einstein's ideas and using them to develop their theory together. It shows Hubble's discovery leading other scientists to create explanations. This demonstrates scientists building on each other's contributions. Strategy: Look for patterns across the text about how scientists interact - using others' ideas, working together, building on discoveries.
original.C: Incorrect. While the passage mentions people had different ideas historically, it shows scientists in the 1960s working together productively, not disagreeing. The emphasis is on collaborative theory-building, not conflict. Disagreement isn't the main message about scientific collaboration here.
original.D: Incorrect. The passage explicitly shows past scientists (Einstein) influencing later scientists who 'studied the ideas of another scientist named Albert Einstein.' This demonstrates how past work directly shapes current understanding. The entire passage shows historical influence on modern science.

rewritten.A: Good try! This tells us old ideas were different, but it doesn't show that scientists today keep changing their ideas. Look for what the story says about scientists now.
rewritten.B: Great job! The story says scientists "sometimes make small changes to the Big Bang Theory." This shows that scientists still change their ideas when they learn new things.
rewritten.C: Not quite! Telling us how hot the Big Bang was gives us facts about what happened. But it doesn't show that scientists keep changing their ideas about space.
rewritten.D: Nice thinking, but this just tells us when something happened. The question asks how scientists keep changing their ideas, not when things formed in space.

original.A: Incorrect. Ancient people having different ideas shows understanding was incomplete in the past, but doesn't show that understanding continues changing today. To show ongoing change, look for evidence about current or recent scientific work, not just historical variety. Review the last paragraph for information about ongoing changes.
original.B: Correct! In the last paragraph, the author states: 'Scientists sometimes make small changes to the Big Bang Theory to match what they have learned.' This directly demonstrates that understanding continues evolving as new information is discovered. Strategy: When asked how an author shows something, look for explicit statements or examples that demonstrate the point. This sentence directly addresses ongoing changes.
original.C: Incorrect. Describing the Big Bang's heat provides information about past conditions but doesn't show that understanding continues changing. This is content about the event itself, not about how scientific understanding evolves. Look for statements about the scientific process rather than about the universe's history.
original.D: Incorrect. Stating when the solar system formed gives a fact about timing but doesn't show that understanding keeps changing. This is a piece of knowledge, not evidence of ongoing revision. To answer this question, find information about how theories get updated, not just facts theories include.

So the correct answer is that he steps into his brother’s footprints. Next time, reread the part that tells what the boy was told to do and pick the answer that matches those exact words.

Earlier it states, “They said that as we walked, I must step quietly into my older brother’s footprints,” so the correct answer is that he steps into his brother’s footprints. The text supports this when it says, “I must step quietly into my older brother’s footprints,” and later, “I… stepped into his big footprints.” Remember to reread and look for exact words in the passage that match the answer choices on similar questions.

original.A: Great job—you identified key details to show that planning and teamwork keep everyone safe. The text says “my brothers told me many times that I must do exactly what they said,” and when Hakan “told us to crouch down” and “put a finger to his lips,” because “it was important that the creature did not know we were there.” For similar questions, look for instructions and signals in the story and ask, “Why are they doing this, and how does it help?”

So the right answer is about planning and teamwork, because the brothers follow Hakan’s plan and wait for his signal while the hunters work together to trap the mammoth. Next time, check that your choice matches the main idea of the whole passage, not just the descriptions.
original.C: You may have focused on the exciting end when the men shout and throw spears, but the text repeats that they must be quiet and follow Hakan: “we walked quietly,” “step into his footprints,” Hakan signals to crouch and be silent, and “they would not use their spears until the giant creature was trapped.” This shows the main idea is planning and teamwork keep everyone safe—the brothers follow Hakan’s plan and stay silent until his signal, and only then do the men attack. original.D: You may have focused on the boy’s fear of being sent away, but look at when Hakan raises his arm, tells them to crouch, and puts a finger to his lips—everyone follows the plan and stays quiet until his signal, which keeps them safe. This shows the main idea is planning and teamwork, not obeying grown-ups in every situation. Next time, reread the key action part and ask, “What helped them stay safe and succeed?”

original.A: It looks like you focused on a small detail—the tools—but the text doesn’t compare tools; it briefly lists what they carry. Notice how the story moves step by step: leaving camp, following footprints, waiting for a mammoth to fall behind, crouching, trapping it, then throwing spears—so the best answer is telling events as they happen in order. Strategy: Make sure your choice fits the whole passage and look for sequence clues that show the order of events.
original.B: Great job—you identified the sequence (chronological order) by noticing the story tells what happens step by step. The text shows this with time clues like “Before we left our camp…,” “We walked until the sun began to sink,” “As soon as one mammoth fell behind,” and “Then my father and uncles threw their spears.” Next time, look for time-order words (before, as soon as, then) and ask yourself, “What happened first, next, and last?”
original.C: You may have focused on the hunting details and thought it was teaching how to hunt, but notice the time-order clues: “Before we left our camp,” “As we walked,” “We walked until the sun began to sink,” “Suddenly,” and “Then,” which show events unfolding, not steps to follow. This means the story is organized by telling events as they happen in order (the correct answer), not by giving directions. Strategy: Look for time words and see if the text uses commands like “First, do…” (how-to) or describes what happened next (story).
original.D: You may have focused on the few lines describing the snow and grass, but the passage mostly follows actions step by step. Notice the time-order clues: “Before we left our camp,” “As we walked,” “Suddenly,” and “Then my father and uncles threw their spears,” which show events happening in order—so “telling events as they happen in order” is correct. Next time, look for time words and make sure your answer fits the whole passage, not just one descriptive part.

The author uses this final image to reinforce that compassionate actions generate positive emotional rewards. When analyzing how authors convey messages, examine the emotional tone and outcomes in concluding passages.
original.B: Incorrect. Adoette didn't sacrifice anything - she successfully completed her job ('For the rest of the day, the two children guarded the corn crop') while also helping the crow. The story shows she managed both responsibilities effectively, not that she gave something up to be kind. The message is about addition, not sacrifice. Review what Adoette accomplished versus what she lost.
original.C: Incorrect. No adults appear in the story's main events. Adoette makes the compassionate choice entirely on her own, despite Awan's opposition ('You are crazy'). The story actually demonstrates that young people can develop and act on compassion independently. Consider who teaches Adoette about compassion in the story.
original.D: Incorrect. The crow is described as an 'enemy' and part of 'the worst enemy during this time' for crops. It wasn't gentle initially - it 'flapped its wings' when picked up. The story shows that compassion can work even with creatures that seem threatening or difficult, not just gentle ones. Think about the crow's role as a crop threat.

rewritten.A: Great job! The word 'proudly' shows Adoette feels good about helping the hurt crow. She made a kind choice and feels happy about it.

original.A: Correct! The word 'proudly' suggests Adoette feels good about her choice despite Awan's disapproval. Throughout the story, she demonstrated confidence: 'I'm going to make it better,' 'Here, let me help you,' and patiently earning the crow's trust. Walking 'proudly' at the end shows she stands by her compassionate decision and feels satisfied with the outcome. When analyzing author's word choices, consider how descriptive words reveal characters' internal feelings about their actions.
original.B: Incorrect. The text focuses on Adoette's relationship with the crow and her journey with Awan, not on seeking attention from others. 'Proudly' describes her feeling about her own choice, not about showing off to others. Personal pride in doing what you believe is right is different from seeking recognition. Consider the difference between internal satisfaction and external validation.
original.C: Incorrect. Nothing suggests Adoette thinks she's superior to Awan. They worked together all day despite disagreeing, and there's no evidence she looked down on him. Pride in her own decision doesn't mean feeling better than someone else. The text shows cooperation, not competition. Review the difference between being proud of your choice and being proud compared to others.
original.D: Incorrect. No adults appear in this part of the story, and there's no mention of Adoette seeking adult approval. Her pride comes from successfully helping the crow and staying true to her values, not from hoping to impress others. The focus is on the completed journey and her achievement, not on future reactions. Consider what the story actually describes versus what it doesn't mention.

rewritten.A: Good try! Plays show character names before each line, but this story has a narrator saying "I" who tells us what happened. This is a story, not a play.

original.A: You may have picked "a play" because the characters talk to each other, but plays usually show the character’s name before each line and give directions about actions. In this passage, a narrator says "I" and tells what happens ("This was my favorite time of year... We always came back to the same maple forest camp"), which shows it is a story being told. So the correct answer is "a narrative," because it is a written story about Meda and Flo. Strategy: Check the text features—if there is a narrator and paragraphs that describe actions and feelings, it’s a narrative; if it shows character names before lines and directions, it’s a play.
original.B: You successfully recognized the genre by noticing it tells a story with characters, dialogue, and events in order. The text supports this when it says, “’Flo, I’ll race you to that tree over there,’ said Meda,” and then describes what happens next as they camp and make maple syrup. Remember to look for story clues—named characters, talking in quotation marks, and a sequence of actions—to spot a narrative in future readings.
original.C: You may have focused on the facts about making maple syrup and thought it was a report, but notice the story parts: it’s told by “I,” has characters (Flo and Meda) who talk (“‘Flo, I’ll race you…’”), and shows events in order (the race, camp, dinner). A report would mostly list facts without people talking or a plot, so the correct answer is a narrative. Strategy: Reread and ask, “Does this have characters, a setting, and things that happen, or is it just facts?” to choose the text type.
original.D: You may have focused on the vivid comparisons (like “flew like an arrow” and “like a shooting star”) and thought it was a poem, but notice the paragraphs and dialogue with quotation marks—“Flo, I’ll race you…,” “I won”—which show regular story writing, not lines and stanzas. The text also tells events in order (racing to the tree, setting up camp, collecting sap), with characters and a setting, which makes it a narrative. Next time, check text features: paragraphs + characters + plot = narrative; short lines or stanzas + rhyme/line breaks often = poem.

original.A: Correct! The story is organized as a narrative with distinct sections marked by horizontal lines. Each section shows different activities: the race, arriving at camp, collecting sap, and returning for dinner. The phrase 'Once we were settled' and section breaks show how each part builds on the earlier sections to tell Flo's story. This structure is typical of narrative organization.
original.B: Incorrect. While the story does include information about maple syrup production, this is not the organizing structure. Reports or informational texts list facts in order, but this text is a personal narrative told from Flo's perspective with dialogue, character thoughts, and story events, not just factual listing.
original.C: Incorrect. This story is not written as letters. Letters have specific formats with greetings, closings, and dates. Instead, this is a first-person narrative where Flo tells about her experiences directly to the reader using 'I' and describing events as they happen.
original.D: Incorrect. Poems use rhyming verses and specific line breaks for poetic effect. This text is written in prose (regular sentences and paragraphs) without rhyme or rhythm patterns. While it describes the forest beautifully, it follows narrative structure, not poetic structure.

The phrase 'This time I took off like an arrow' echoes the opening race, and the smell of cooking dinner signals the end of the day's activities, providing closure to the narrative.
original.B: Incorrect. An introduction appears at the beginning of a story to set up characters, setting, or problems. This section appears at the very end of the text, after all the activities have been described. The actual introduction shows Meda and Flo racing, which happens much earlier.

This is a short story with natural breaks between activities, and this final section completes the same story rather than starting a new topic.

rewritten.D: Not quite! Calling their dog happens once in the story, not over and over. This shows they're getting ready to hunt, not something that repeats with time.

original.A: Correct! The story begins during a specific season ('cold time when frost covers the ground') and ends explaining what happens 'each autumn.' This seasonal frame at the beginning foreshadows that the myth will explain a yearly, repeating natural event. Good readers notice when stories emphasize seasons or cycles.
original.B: Incorrect. The brothers' hunting skills are important to the plot but don't indicate repetition or cycles. This detail describes character traits, not seasonal patterns. Look for details that mention time periods or recurring events.
original.C: Incorrect. The bear's night visits show its behavior but don't suggest yearly repetition or cycles. This detail creates the problem to solve, not a pattern that repeats. Consider which details connect to seasons or time cycles.
original.D: Incorrect. Calling the dog is a one-time action in the story, not something indicating repetition. This detail shows preparation for the hunt, not cyclical patterns. Think about which details relate to seasonal or repeating timeframes.

rewritten.A: You got it! The brothers focus so hard on hunting that they don't notice the magic happening around them. This shows how caring deeply about something can lead to amazing things.
rewritten.B: Good try! But this isn't about being careful while walking. The story shows the brothers were so focused on their hunt that magical things happened without them knowing.
rewritten.C: Nice thinking, but they're not on a mountain - they're in the sky! The story isn't warning about danger but showing how their focus led to something magical.
rewritten.D: Not quite! The bear is running away from the brothers, not controlling them. The brothers are chasing the bear the whole time.

original.A: Correct! The brothers are so focused on catching the bear that they don't notice they've entered the sky realm until after they succeed. This reveals that complete dedication to a goal can lead to extraordinary, even magical outcomes without awareness. When analyzing complex texts, notice what characters' focus causes them to miss.
original.B: Incorrect. The message isn't a practical safety lesson about watching steps. The transformation is magical and purposeful, not a mistake or accident to avoid. Myths convey deeper meanings than simple safety tips. Consider the symbolic meaning of their journey.
original.C: Incorrect. The text clarifies they're not on a mountain but in the sky, and this isn't presented as danger. The transformation serves the myth's purpose of explaining sky phenomena, not warning about mountains. Think about why the sky setting matters to the story's ending.
original.D: Incorrect. The bear runs from the brothers - they're chasing it, not being controlled by it. The bear's magic created obstacles (worms, disappearing tracks) but didn't control the brothers' direction. Reread who is pursuing whom throughout the chase.

rewritten.A: Good try! The story does say the bear changed food into worms, but that's not what the hunters found. The hunters found "tracks along the riverbank" which is the right answer.
rewritten.B: Nice thinking, but the bear moving quietly isn't about magic. The story talks about finding the bear's "tracks" which shows its magic power over the hunters.

rewritten.D: Great job! You found where the hunters discovered the bear's magic. The story says "if we find Nyah-gwaheh's tracks" and those tracks showed the bear's power.

original.A: You may have focused on a cool detail, because the story says, “Nyah-gwaheh had used magic to change his food into worms,” but that tells what the bear did—not what the hunters found. The question asks what the hunters discovered, and the text points to finding the bear’s tracks (“If we find Nyah-gwaheh’s tracks and follow them…”), so the correct answer is that they found its tracks along the riverbank. Next time, reread the question and pick the detail that answers it, not just any interesting part.

Your choice isn’t in the story, and the text says “Like a monstrous ghost, Nyah-gwaheh moved through the forest” and “Nyah-gwaheh began to run”—these tell how, not where. The right answer works because it names the place the tracks were found—along the riverbank—so it matches the question; next time, reread the question and choose the sentence that gives the where.
original.C: You may have added an idea that isn’t in the story—the text never says the Great Bear rested in a cave. Instead, the story talks about the hunters finding and following its tracks (“When we follow the great bear’s tracks, they disappear”), and it says the tracks were along the riverbank, which matches the correct answer. Next time, reread to find the exact line that answers the question and pick the choice that uses the same words from the text.
original.D: Great job—you identified key details by focusing on where the hunters found signs of the bear. The text supports this by highlighting the tracks: “If we find Nyah-gwaheh’s tracks and follow them…” and Four Eyes “sniffed the ground,” showing how they located the trail. Next time, look for location words (like along, near, or by) to spot where an event happens.

rewritten.A: Good try! Bears can visit villages at night in real life. The story shows something much more magical happening to prove the bear has special powers.
rewritten.B: Not quite! Real bears can stand up and scratch trees to show their territory. Look for something that no normal bear could ever do.
rewritten.C: You got it! When "tracks disappear," that's impossible magic. Normal animal footprints can't just vanish into thin air!
rewritten.D: Nice thinking, but regular bears can run far across land. The story tells us about something much more magical than just running fast.

original.A: Incorrect. Coming into a village at night is unusual behavior but not supernatural. Regular bears can enter villages. Look for evidence of abilities that break natural laws or are impossible for normal animals.
original.B: Incorrect. Making scratch marks by rearing on back legs is normal bear behavior, even if these marks are very high. This shows the bear's size but not magical powers. Find evidence of something impossible for any normal animal.
original.C: Correct! Tracks that disappear violate natural laws - footprints cannot simply vanish. The village leader states this as evidence of the bear's magic, and the text confirms this is supernatural. When finding evidence for claims, look for details that show impossible or magical events.
original.D: Incorrect. Running across valleys and hills shows endurance and speed but not magic. Normal bears can run long distances over terrain. Search for evidence of abilities that defy nature's rules.

rewritten.A: Great job! The story says the tallest brother "could not reach them," showing the bear was huge. The high scratches told the brothers this bear was much bigger than normal.
rewritten.B: Good try! The scratches weren't about eating though. The story says the bear made marks to show "this was its home," not because it was hungry.
rewritten.C: Not quite! The scratches showed the bear's territory, not where it was going. The brothers had to follow tracks to see which way the bear went.
rewritten.D: Nice thinking, but no! A bear making high scratches shows it's big and strong, not scared. The bear was marking its area to warn others away.

original.A: Correct! The text shows the tallest brother trying to touch the highest scratches but being unable to reach them, which demonstrated the bear's extraordinary size. The text also states these high marks made the brothers realize the bear's power. When answering questions, look for what characters learn from evidence they observe.
original.B: Incorrect. The scratches were territorial marks, not feeding signs. The text explains the bear made these to show the territory was its home, not to indicate eating. Reread what the passage says about why animals make scratch marks.
original.C: Incorrect. Scratch marks on trees show territory, not travel direction. The brothers followed tracks and Four Eyes' nose to determine where the bear went, not the scratches. Look at what different types of evidence tell the hunters.
original.D: Incorrect. Standing tall to scratch high marks shows confidence and strength, not fear. The bear was marking its territory to warn others away, showing dominance. Consider what the behavior of marking territory demonstrates about an animal.

rewritten.A: Nice thinking, but running fast isn't what makes him different. The story shows he's lazy and always complains about work.
rewritten.B: You got it! The fourth brother asks "Do we have any food?" while his brothers focus on hunting. He complains instead of helping.
rewritten.C: Good try, but all the brothers have spears. The fourth brother is different because he's lazy, not because of his weapons.
rewritten.D: Not quite! The other brothers talk about the bear's magic. The fourth brother only cares about food and rest.

original.A: Incorrect. While the fourth brother does run fast after resting, this single action doesn't show his overall difference. His defining characteristic throughout the story is avoiding work, not occasional speed. Look for patterns in behavior across multiple scenes.
original.B: Correct! The text repeatedly shows the fourth brother asking about food, pretending injury, and needing to be carried while his brothers remain dedicated to the hunt. These consistent behaviors contrast sharply with his brothers' focus. When comparing characters, notice repeated behavioral patterns that create contrast.
original.C: Incorrect. All brothers carry spears, and the text doesn't indicate the fourth brother has more or different weapons. His distinction is in attitude and effort, not equipment. Check what the text actually says about what each brother carries.
original.D: Incorrect. The second and third brothers discuss the bear's magic and how to overcome it, not the fourth brother. His focus is on food and rest, not understanding magic. Reread which brothers make statements about the bear's powers.

rewritten.A: You got it! The story says Four Eyes "got close enough to bite its tail" because the bear was getting tired. This shows the dog caught up to the bear!
rewritten.B: Good try! But Four Eyes is biting the bear, which means he's still chasing it hard. A dog who wants to rest wouldn't bite the bear's tail!
rewritten.C: Nice thinking, but Four Eyes shows he's brave by biting the bear! A scared dog would run away, not bite a big bear's tail.
rewritten.D: Not quite! Four Eyes bites the tail all by himself before the fourth brother does anything. The dog doesn't need help here!

original.A: Correct! The text states 'Four Eyes got close enough to bite its tail' right after explaining the bear was getting tired. This shows the dog successfully closed the distance during the chase. When reading, notice how authors use physical actions to show spatial relationships and progress. The bite proves the hunters are catching up.
original.B: Incorrect. Biting the bear shows Four Eyes is actively chasing, not wanting to rest. This aggressive action happens while pursuing the bear, showing continued effort. Look at the context - is the dog attacking or retreating?
original.C: Incorrect. Biting the bear demonstrates bravery and aggression, not fear. A frightened dog would retreat, not attack. Notice that Four Eyes has been confidently tracking the magical bear throughout the entire story.
original.D: Incorrect. Four Eyes bites the tail independently before the fourth brother does anything. The dog's successful action happens first, then the brother acts later. Pay attention to the sequence of events in the paragraph.

rewritten.A: Good try! The characters don't really change much - the fourth brother still asks for food throughout the story. The story follows their journey step by step instead.
rewritten.B: Nice thinking, but the story doesn't explain why bears are magical. It just tells about their trip "from start to finish" as they chase the bear.
rewritten.C: Great job! You noticed the story follows their journey in order from "a messenger came" to chasing the bear into the sky. Look for time words to spot this pattern!
rewritten.D: Not quite! The story doesn't compare different ways to hunt. It tells about one journey "on the way" to help the village and chase the bear.

original.A: You may have thought the author shows character change, but the story doesn’t really show that—the fourth brother keeps asking for food and even pretends to fall, while the others stay focused on the hunt. Look at the step-by-step clues: “On the way…,” “When the brothers entered the village…,” “As they ran, day turned to night,” and then “up into the heavens”—this shows a journey from start to finish, which is the correct answer. Next time, look for order words (first, next, when, suddenly) to tell if the passage is organized by events.
original.B: You may have focused on the “magic powers” detail, but the text doesn’t explain why the bear is magical—it just shows things it does, like turning the food to worms and leading them into the sky. The story is told in order like a trip: it begins when “a messenger came to their village,” the brothers chase the bear (“Nyah-gwaheh began to run… Higher and higher they climbed”), and it ends with “And so it remains today.” So the correct answer is “by following a journey from start to finish.” Strategy: Reread and check that your answer matches the whole story, not just one detail.
original.C: Great job identifying the text structure (sequence) by seeing the story follows a journey from start to finish. The text supports this with steps like 'The brothers followed... Nyah-gwaheh began to run... The great bear ran across valleys and hills... Higher and higher they climbed,' and later 'We are high up in the sky.' When answering similar questions, look for time/order words (then, suddenly) and track how characters move from place to place.
original.D: You may have thought the text compares hunting methods because it’s about hunters, but there is no comparison of different ways to hunt. Look at the sequence of events: a messenger asks for help, they find tracks, run across hills, climb a mountain, rise into the sky, and “each autumn” the chase continues—this shows a journey told in time order. To get the right answer, look for time-order clues like “one day,” “on the way,” “suddenly,” and “each autumn,” which show the author organizes the story by following a journey from start to finish.

rewritten.A: You got it! The story starts with a "great bear" causing trouble in the village and ends with that same bear chase becoming stars forever in the sky.
rewritten.B: Good try! The brothers were already "good hunters" at the start, so their skills didn't get better. The story moves the bear problem from earth to sky instead.
rewritten.C: Not quite! The messenger just brings news at the beginning and then disappears. The village doesn't get saved - the bear chase just moves to the sky.
rewritten.D: Nice thinking, but the brothers never go home! They stay in the sky forever chasing the bear, not back in their village.

original.A: Correct! The story begins with a village troubled by a bear and ends with that same bear chase continuing forever in the sky, explaining autumn's colors. This structure transforms a local problem into an eternal, cosmic explanation. When analyzing story structure, trace how the initial situation evolves to the conclusion.
original.B: Incorrect. The brothers are already described as 'good hunters' at the beginning, and the story doesn't focus on their skills improving. The structural connection is about location transformation (earth to sky), not skill development. Consider how settings change from start to finish.
original.C: Incorrect. The messenger simply delivers information at the start and doesn't appear again. The village isn't saved in a traditional sense - the chase moves to the sky and continues forever. Think about what actually happens to the original problem.
original.D: Incorrect. The brothers never return home - they remain in the sky chasing the bear eternally. The story's structure moves from earth to sky, not back home. Reread the ending to see where the characters remain.

rewritten.A: You got it! The text says they "did not say a word" and picked up their spears right away. This shows they are brave and want to help quickly.
rewritten.B: Not quite! The brothers act right away without talking or waiting. The story says they "did not say a word" and got their spears immediately.
rewritten.C: Good try! The brothers never ask about money or payment. They just grab their spears and go help the village right away.
rewritten.D: Nice thinking, but the brothers don't show worry at first. They grab their spears quickly without asking questions or being scared.

original.A: Correct! The text states 'The four hunters did not say a word. They picked up their spears and called to their dog.' This immediate action without discussion or questions shows courage and willingness to help. When analyzing characters, notice what they do (or don't do) in response to requests.
original.B: Incorrect. The opposite is true - the brothers act immediately without deliberation. The text emphasizes they 'did not say a word' and took action right away. Careful thinking would involve discussion or questions.
original.C: Incorrect. Payment or reward is never mentioned or asked about by the brothers. They respond immediately to the need without discussing compensation. Look at what the brothers say and do - or in this case, what they don't say.
original.D: Incorrect. While they later acknowledge the bear's magic, their immediate response shows no hesitation or expressed worry. Acting without pause suggests confidence, not fear. Notice the contrast between silent action and worried discussion.

rewritten.A: You got it! The story shows "another carried his spear" because the lazy brother makes extra work for everyone else.
rewritten.B: Good try! But the fourth brother is faking being hurt to get out of work. This isn't about helping family nicely.
rewritten.C: Not quite! The story doesn't talk about going slow. It shows how the lazy brother makes his brothers do his work too.
rewritten.D: Nice thinking, but this isn't good teamwork! Real teamwork means everyone helps, not one person making others do everything.

original.A: Correct! This detail emphasizes the fourth brother's laziness and selfishness - two brothers must carry him and another carries his weapon, meaning three brothers do his work. The author includes this to highlight his character flaw and its impact on others. When analyzing why authors include details, consider what character traits or themes they emphasize.
original.B: Incorrect. While the brothers do help him, the author's purpose isn't to teach a positive lesson about family help. The context shows the fourth brother is faking injury to avoid work, making this a negative example. Consider whether this is presented as admirable or problematic behavior.
original.C: Incorrect. Speed isn't the focus of this detail - the author emphasizes the burden placed on others, not travel pace. The detail highlights unfairness, not logistics. Think about what the author wants readers to notice about the fourth brother.
original.D: Incorrect. This isn't positive teamwork - it's one person forcing others to do his share. Real cooperation involves everyone contributing, not one person creating extra burden. Notice the contrast with earlier scenes where brothers truly cooperate in hunting.

rewritten.A: Exactly! The brother says "the bear's magic will not work on us if we find its tracks first." This shows they know how to beat magic.
rewritten.B: Good try! Bringing a dog helps with hunting, but it doesn't show they understand magic. The story shows they know special magic rules.
rewritten.C: Not quite! Four Eyes' looks don't show what the brothers know about magic. Look for what the brothers say about beating magic.
rewritten.D: Nice thinking, but the messenger just tells facts. This doesn't show the brothers understand magic. They share their own magic knowledge later.

original.A: Correct! This statement shows the brothers know specific magical rules - finding tracks first will prevent the bear's magic from working on them. This knowledge demonstrates their understanding of how to counter supernatural threats. When looking for evidence of understanding, find statements that show characters know strategies or solutions.
original.B: Incorrect. Bringing a tracking dog shows good hunting practice but doesn't demonstrate understanding of how to overcome magic specifically. This is standard preparation, not magical knowledge. Look for details about supernatural solutions, not regular hunting tactics.
original.C: Incorrect. Four Eyes' markings are physical characteristics, not evidence that the brothers understand magical countermeasures. The dog's appearance doesn't show the brothers' knowledge. Focus on what the brothers say or do that reveals their understanding.
original.D: Incorrect. The messenger provides information, but this doesn't show the brothers' understanding of overcoming magic. This is someone else giving facts, not the brothers demonstrating knowledge. Search for evidence of what the brothers themselves know.

rewritten.A: Good try! North is where Crow started, but that's not where daylight is. The story says he "agreed to travel south" to find it.
rewritten.B: Great job! You found the right direction in the story. The text says "Crow agreed to travel south" to get daylight.
rewritten.C: Nice thinking, but the sun doesn't help here! The story tells us Crow "agreed to travel south" to find daylight, not east.
